lexicon_requests.reason: Rare superscription (only Pss 16, 56-60) - etymology debated: gold? inscription? atonement?
Crux interpretum in v.2 phrase טוֹבָתִי בַּל־עָלֶיךָ - semantic range needed for syntactic resolution
Ambiguous referent in v.3 - can mean faithful saints OR pagan 'holy ones'/deities
V.3 'mighty/noble ones' - semantic range: human nobles OR divine beings?
Unusual verb for religious devotion in v.4 'hasten after another god' - suggests urgency
V.4 libations terminology - what are 'libations from/of blood'?
First of four inheritance terms in v.5 - distinguish from חֵלֶק semantically
Second inheritance term in v.5 - overlap with מְנָת or distinct nuance?
Lot/fate terminology in v.5 applied to God - technical land-distribution term becoming theological metaphor
V.6 measuring lines/cords - technical surveying term (Josh 17:5, Mic 2:5)
V.7 kidneys as seat of conscience/moral instruction - why not heart? Anthropological significance
V.7 instruct/discipline - kidneys as subject of moral formation is unusual
V.8 'I have set/placed' YHWH before me - intentional positioning verb
V.9 'my glory' - ambiguous: liver? soul/self? LXX has 'tongue' - major interpretive crux
V.10 Pit/corruption - can mean place (pit) OR process (decay/corruption) - crucial for resurrection interpretation
V.11 final word - semantic range: perpetuity? eternity? victory? endurance? Shapes eschatological trajectory

concordance_requests.purpose: Track this syntactically ambiguous phrase - does it appear elsewhere in this construction? [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Identify other 'holy ones in the land' references to clarify whether faithful or pagan [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse] [GUARANTEED: Added 1 forms from verse 3]
Track 'hasten after another god' formula - is this idiomatic for apostasy? [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Find other 'blood libations' references to understand cultic context [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Track double inheritance language - portion of my share pattern [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Find other 'YHWH is my portion' declarations - esp. Levitical theology (Num 18:20) [GUARANTEED: Added 1 forms from verse 5]
Track measuring lines fallen idiom for land allocation [GUARANTEED: Added 1 forms from verse 6]
Find other instances of kidneys as moral instructor - unique anthropology? [GUARANTEED: Added 1 forms from verse 7]
Track 'I have set YHWH before me' formula - orientation language
Track 'not abandon soul to Sheol' formula - other death-transcendence texts [GUARANTEED: Added 1 forms from verse 10]
Find 'see the Pit/corruption' usage elsewhere - place or process? [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Track 'path of life' in wisdom literature (Prov 2:19, 5:6, 10:17) vs. eschatological usage [FIXED: Using exact phrase from verse]
Track joys in God's presence formula - intimacy with divine face
Track delights in God's right hand forever - eternal communion language

figurative_requests.reason: Refuge metaphor - spatial/protective imagery for divine protection | Vehicle: refuge | Related terms: refuge, shelter, protect, guard, safety, hide, cover, fortress, stronghold, tower, rock, seek refuge, find shelter
Cup imagery - possibly meal fellowship and blessing (cf. Ps 23:5) | Vehicle: cup | Related terms: cup, drink, wine, portion, share, feast, table, meal, drink offering, my cup

Inheritance/land metaphor - territorial blessing vocabulary applied to God Himself | Vehicle: inheritance | Related terms: inheritance, portion, share, lot, land, estate, allotment, inherit, possess, territory, my portion, my inheritance, my lot

Measuring lines/surveyor imagery - land division applied metaphorically to divine portion | Vehicle: measuring line | Related terms: line, cord, measure, boundary, border, divide, survey, allot, plot, measuring line, measuring cord, boundaries

Night as revelatory time - darkness/vulnerability as context for divine instruction | Vehicle: night | Related terms: night, darkness, evening, sleep, dream, vision, midnight, nighttime, nocturnal, at night, in the night
Right hand position - spatial metaphor for protection, honor, and power | Vehicle: right hand | Related terms: right hand, right, hand, right side, at my right, my right hand, your right hand

Stability/shaking imagery - earthquake metaphor for security vs. instability | Vehicle: shake | Related terms: shake, shaken, tremble, move, totter, stumble, slip, fall, stable, firm, not shake, not be shaken
Body parts as synecdoche - heart, glory/liver, flesh represent whole-person response | Vehicle: heart | Related terms: heart, flesh, body, soul, spirit, mind, being, whole person, my heart, my flesh

Sheol/Pit imagery - death realm/underworld as place of separation from God | Vehicle: Sheol | Related terms: Sheol, pit, grave, death, underworld, corruption, decay, tomb, depths, the Pit, realm of death

Path/way metaphor - journey through life toward ultimate destination with God | Vehicle: path | Related terms: path, way, road, walk, journey, course, route, direction, way of life, path of life, my path

Face/presence imagery - intimacy with God, seeing divine face (usually forbidden) | Vehicle: face | Related terms: face, presence, countenance, see, behold, gaze, look, before, your face, your presence, in your presence

commentary_requests.reason: Opening invocation with rare michtam superscription - how do commentators interpret its significance and the protection petition?
Crux interpretum טוֹבָתִי בַּל־עָלֶיךָ - traditional exegesis of this syntactically ambiguous phrase and divine name progression
Most obscure verse - who are the 'holy ones in the land'? Traditional identification of righteous vs. pagan 'holy ones'
Clear rejection of other gods - commentators on blood libations and refusing to speak divine names
Theological center with fourfold inheritance terminology - how commentators interpret God as portion/inheritance
Continuation of inheritance metaphor - traditional understanding of measuring lines and pleasant places
Kidneys instruct at night - commentators on visceral anthropology and nocturnal divine guidance
Setting YHWH before me continually - traditional interpretation of intentional divine orientation and stability
Triple body-part response - commentators on 'my glory' (liver? soul? tongue?) and holistic joy
Psalm's theological apex on Sheol/Pit - traditional Jewish interpretation of death-transcendence and messianic application
Climactic verse on path of life and eternal joy - commentators on seeing God's face and delights in right hand forever

macro_questions: What is the syntactic relationship and correct interpretation of vv. 3-4? Are the 'holy ones in the land' faithful Israelites the psalmist admires, or pagan deities/devotees? How does the grammar of v. 3b ('all my desire concerning them') connect to v. 4a?

How does the land inheritance terminology (חֶלֶק, גּוֹרָל, נַחֲלָה, חֲבָלִים) function when applied to God Himself? What are the Pentateuchal parallels for Levites receiving YHWH as their inheritance (Num 18:20; Deut 10:9, 18:1-2), and how does this psalm democratize that concept?

What is the precise meaning of טוֹבָתִי בַּל־עָלֶיךָ in v. 2? Does it mean 'my good is not apart from You' (NJPS), 'You are my good, nothing above You,' or 'my good does not reach up to You' (acknowledging human inability to benefit God, cf. Job 22:2-3)?

What is the significance of כִלְיוֹת ('kidneys') instructing the psalmist at night (v. 7)? How does this relate to other biblical references to kidneys as the seat of conscience/testing (Pss 7:10, 26:2; Jer 11:20, 17:10)?

How should v. 10's confidence about Sheol/Pit be interpreted? Is this (a) protection from premature/violent death, (b) hope for resurrection, (c) assurance of ongoing communion with God transcending death, or (d) simply metaphorical language for deliverance from danger? What are the comparative data from other Psalms (Pss 30:3, 49:15, 73:23-26)?

What is the force and aspect of שִׁוִּיתִי ('I have set/placed') YHWH before me (v. 8)? Is this a completed decisive act, or continuous practice? How does this verb choice shape the theology of intentional divine orientation?

What does כָּבוֹד ('glory') refer to in v. 9? Is it the liver (paralleling heart and flesh as body parts), the soul/self, or God's glory? What is the triadic structure of heart-glory-flesh trying to communicate about human wholeness?
How does נֶֽצַח (v. 11) function semantically—'forever,' 'perpetuity,' 'victory,' 'endurance'? Does it suggest eternal life in God's presence, or enduring joy in this life?

What is the 'path of life' (אֹרַח חַיִּים, v. 11)? Is this wisdom language (cf. Prov 2:19, 5:6, 10:17), cultic instruction, or something more eschatological? How does it relate to ANE journey-of-life metaphors?
What is the meaning and function of the 'michtam' (מִכְתָּם) designation? Does etymology from כתם ('gold'), כתם ('inscription'), or כפר ('atone') illuminate the psalm's use or original setting?
micro_questions: What is the exact syntactic and semantic sense of טוֹבָתִי בַּל־עָלֶיךָ in v.2? How does this phrase establish the theological foundation for vv.5-6's inheritance language?
Who are the קְדוֹשִׁים and אַדִּירֵי in v.3, and how does the ambiguous phrase כׇּל־חֶפְצִי־בָם relate syntactically to v.4's clear rejection? Is the ambiguity intentional?

How does the concentration of land-inheritance terminology in vv.5-6 (מְנָת, חֵלֶק, כּוֹס, גּוֹרָל, חֲבָלִים, נַחֲלָה) function as theological metaphor? What is gained by applying territorial language to God Himself?
Why do the kidneys (כִלְיוֹתָי) instruct the psalmist at night (v.7) rather than the heart? What is the anthropological and theological significance of this visceral internal guidance?
What is the referent of כָּבוֹד in v.9 - liver (parallel organ to heart/flesh), soul/self, or something else? How does the LXX's 'tongue' interpretation change the meaning?

How should v.10's confidence about Sheol/Pit be interpreted in its historical context - as protection from premature death, nascent resurrection hope, ongoing communion transcending death, or metaphorical deliverance language? How does this compare to Psalms 49:15 and 73:23-26?
What is the semantic range and force of נֶצַח in v.11 - perpetuity, eternity, victory, or endurance? How does the final word choice shape the psalm's eschatological trajectory?
How does the right hand inclusio (vv.8, 11) function structurally and theologically - what is the progression from God at the psalmist's right hand to delights in God's right hand?
What is the relationship between the 'path of life' (אֹרַח חַיִּים, v.11) and wisdom literature? Is this temporal guidance through earthly life or eschatological trajectory toward eternal life?
What does the michtam (מִכְתָּם) superscription signify, and how might its uncertain etymology (gold? inscription? atonement?) inform the psalm's function or theological emphasis?
